segment.source: Objective: To set up DirectX resources in a C++ Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app and to display a solid color.
segment.target: Objective: To set up DirectX resources in a C++ Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app and to display a solid color.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We assume that you are familiar with C++.
segment.target: We assume that you are familiar with C++.

segment.source: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.
segment.target: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.

segment.target: 1. Declaring Direct3D interface variables with ComPtr

segment.target: We declare Direct3D interface variables with the ComPtr smart pointer template from the Windows Runtime C++ Template Library (WRL), so we can manage the lifetime of those variables in an exception safe manner.

segment.source: We can then use those variables to access the ComPtr class and its members.
segment.target: We can then use those variables to access the ComPtr class and its members.

segment.source: 2. Creating the Direct3D device
segment.target: 2. Creating the Direct3D device

segment.source: To use the Direct3D API to render a scene, we must first create a Direct3D device that represents the display adapter.
segment.target: To use the Direct3D API to render a scene, we must first create a Direct3D device that represents the display adapter.

segment.source: To create the Direct3D device, we call the D3D11CreateDevice function.
segment.target: To create the Direct3D device, we call the D3D11CreateDevice function.

segment.source: We specify levels 9.1 through 11.1 in the array of D3D\_FEATURE\_LEVEL values.
segment.target: We specify levels 9.1 through 11.1 in the array of D3D\_FEATURE\_LEVEL values.

segment.source: Direct3D walks the array in order and returns the highest supported feature level.
segment.target: Direct3D walks the array in order and returns the highest supported feature level.

segment.source: So, to get the highest feature level available, we list the D3D\_FEATURE\_LEVEL array entries from highest to lowest.
segment.target: So, to get the highest feature level available, we list the D3D\_FEATURE\_LEVEL array entries from highest to lowest.

segment.source: We pass the D3D11\_CREATE\_DEVICE\_BGRA\_SUPPORT flag to the Flags parameter to make Direct3D resources interoperate with Direct2D.
segment.target: We pass the D3D11\_CREATE\_DEVICE\_BGRA\_SUPPORT flag to the Flags parameter to make Direct3D resources interoperate with Direct2D.

segment.source: If we use the debug build, we also pass the D3D11\_CREATE\_DEVICE\_DEBUG flag.
segment.target: If we use the debug build, we also pass the D3D11\_CREATE\_DEVICE\_DEBUG flag.

segment.source: For more info about debugging apps, see Using the debug layer to debug apps.
segment.target: For more info about debugging apps, see Using the debug layer to debug apps.

segment.source: We obtain the Direct3D 11.1 device (ID3D11Device1) and device context (ID3D11DeviceContext1) by querying the Direct3D 11 device and device context that are returned from D3D11CreateDevice.
segment.target: We obtain the Direct3D 11.1 device (ID3D11Device1) and device context (ID3D11DeviceContext1) by querying the Direct3D 11 device and device context that are returned from D3D11CreateDevice.

segment.source: 3. Creating the swap chain
segment.target: 3. Creating the swap chain

segment.source: Next, we create a swap chain that the device uses for rendering and display.
segment.target: Next, we create a swap chain that the device uses for rendering and display.

segment.source: We declare and initialize a DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_DESC1 structure to describe the swap chain.
segment.target: We declare and initialize a DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_DESC1 structure to describe the swap chain.

segment.source: Then, we set up the swap chain as flip-model (that is, a swap chain that has the DXGI\_SWAP\_EFFECT\_FLIP\_SEQUENTIAL value set in the SwapEffect member) and set the Format member to DXGI\_FORMAT\_B8G8R8A8\_UNORM.
segment.target: Then, we set up the swap chain as flip-model (that is, a swap chain that has the DXGI\_SWAP\_EFFECT\_FLIP\_SEQUENTIAL value set in the SwapEffect member) and set the Format member to DXGI\_FORMAT\_B8G8R8A8\_UNORM.

segment.source: We set the Count member of the DXGI\_SAMPLE\_DESC structure that the SampleDesc member specifies to 1 and the Quality member of DXGI\_SAMPLE\_DESC to zero because flip-model doesn’t support multiple sample antialiasing (MSAA).
segment.target: We set the Count member of the DXGI\_SAMPLE\_DESC structure that the SampleDesc member specifies to 1 and the Quality member of DXGI\_SAMPLE\_DESC to zero because flip-model doesn’t support multiple sample antialiasing (MSAA).

segment.source: We set the BufferCount member to 2 so the swap chain can use a front buffer to present to the display device and a back buffer that serves as the render target.
segment.target: We set the BufferCount member to 2 so the swap chain can use a front buffer to present to the display device and a back buffer that serves as the render target.

segment.source: We obtain the underlying DXGI device by querying the Direct3D 11.1 device.
segment.target: We obtain the underlying DXGI device by querying the Direct3D 11.1 device.

segment.source: To minimize power consumption, which is important to do on battery-powered devices such as laptops and tablets, we call the IDXGIDevice1::SetMaximumFrameLatency method with 1 as the maximum number of back buffer frames that DXGI can queue.
segment.target: To minimize power consumption, which is important to do on battery-powered devices such as laptops and tablets, we call the IDXGIDevice1::SetMaximumFrameLatency method with 1 as the maximum number of back buffer frames that DXGI can queue.

segment.source: This ensures that the app is rendered only after the vertical blank.
segment.target: This ensures that the app is rendered only after the vertical blank.

segment.source: To finally create the swap chain, we need to get the parent factory from the DXGI device.
segment.target: To finally create the swap chain, we need to get the parent factory from the DXGI device.

segment.source: We call IDXGIDevice::GetAdapter to get the adapter for the device, and then call IDXGIObject::GetParent on the adapter to get the parent factory (IDXGIFactory2).
segment.target: We call IDXGIDevice::GetAdapter to get the adapter for the device, and then call IDXGIObject::GetParent on the adapter to get the parent factory (IDXGIFactory2).

segment.source: To create the swap chain, we call IDXGIFactory2::CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow with the swap-chain descriptor and the app’s core window.
segment.target: To create the swap chain, we call IDXGIFactory2::CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow with the swap-chain descriptor and the app’s core window.

segment.source: 4. Creating the render-target view
segment.target: 4. Creating the render-target view

segment.source: To render graphics to the window, we need to create a render-target view.
segment.target: To render graphics to the window, we need to create a render-target view.

segment.source: We call IDXGISwapChain::GetBuffer to get the swap chain’s back buffer to use when we create the render-target view.
segment.target: We call IDXGISwapChain::GetBuffer to get the swap chain’s back buffer to use when we create the render-target view.

segment.source: We specify the back buffer as a 2D texture (ID3D11Texture2D).
segment.target: We specify the back buffer as a 2D texture (ID3D11Texture2D).

segment.source: To create the render-target view, we call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView with the swap chain’s back buffer.
segment.target: To create the render-target view, we call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView with the swap chain’s back buffer.

segment.source: We must specify to draw to the entire core window by specifying the view port (D3D11\_VIEWPORT) as the full size of the swap chain's back buffer.
segment.target: We must specify to draw to the entire core window by specifying the view port (D3D11\_VIEWPORT) as the full size of the swap chain's back buffer.

segment.source: We use the view port in a call to ID3D11DeviceContext::RSSetViewports to bind the view port to the rasterizer stage of the pipeline.
segment.target: We use the view port in a call to ID3D11DeviceContext::RSSetViewports to bind the view port to the rasterizer stage of the pipeline.

segment.source: The rasterizer stage converts vector information into a raster image.
segment.target: The rasterizer stage converts vector information into a raster image.

segment.source: In this case, we don't require a conversion because we are just displaying a solid color.
segment.target: In this case, we don't require a conversion because we are just displaying a solid color.

segment.source: 5. Presenting the rendered image
segment.target: 5. Presenting the rendered image

segment.source: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.
segment.target: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.

segment.source: In this loop, we call:
segment.target: In this loop, we call:

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView to clear the render target to a solid color.
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView to clear the render target to a solid color.

segment.source: IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.
segment.target: IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.

segment.source: Because we previously set the maximum frame latency to 1, Windows generally slows down the render loop to the screen refresh rate, typically around 60 Hz.
segment.target: Because we previously set the maximum frame latency to 1, Windows generally slows down the render loop to the screen refresh rate, typically around 60 Hz.

segment.source: Windows slows down the render loop by making the app sleep when the app calls Present.
segment.target: Windows slows down the render loop by making the app sleep when the app calls Present.

segment.source: Windows makes the app sleep until the screen is refreshed.

segment.source: 6. Resizing the app window and the swap chain’s buffer
segment.target: 6. Resizing the app window and the swap chain’s buffer

segment.source: If the size of the app window changes, the app must resize the swap chain’s buffers, recreate the render-target view, and then present the resized rendered image.
segment.target: If the size of the app window changes, the app must resize the swap chain’s buffers, recreate the render-target view, and then present the resized rendered image.

segment.source: To resize the swap chain’s buffers, we call IDXGISwapChain::ResizeBuffers.
segment.target: To resize the swap chain’s buffers, we call IDXGISwapChain::ResizeBuffers.

segment.source: In this call, we leave the number of buffers and the format of the buffers unchanged (the BufferCount parameter to two and the NewFormat parameter to DXGI\_FORMAT\_B8G8R8A8\_UNORM).
segment.target: In this call, we leave the number of buffers and the format of the buffers unchanged (the BufferCount parameter to two and the NewFormat parameter to DXGI\_FORMAT\_B8G8R8A8\_UNORM).

segment.source: We make the size of the swap chain’s back buffer the same size as the resized window.
segment.target: We make the size of the swap chain’s back buffer the same size as the resized window.

segment.source: After we resize the swap chain’s buffers, we create the new render target and present the new rendered image similarly to when we initialized the app.
segment.target: After we resize the swap chain’s buffers, we create the new render target and present the new rendered image similarly to when we initialized the app.
